cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: The following steamers are expected to leave Port Said on or about the following dates:--
Port-Said to London via Brindisi
The BRINDISI steamer leaves PORT-SAID after arrival of Indian Mail. Combined steamer and sleeping car fare from PORT-SAID to LONDON via BRINDISI or via MARSEILLES £25.9.11
To the East.

The Mail Steamers leave SUEZ for ADEN and BOMBAY every Wednesday, and for AUSTRALIA and CHINA every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for CALCUTTA, fortnightly, and another for JAPAN. Passengers can embark at PORT-SAID.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Passengers are allowed to break the voyage at any intermediate Ports and proceed by following steamer in which there may be accomodation.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: Mr. W. Ernest Walton has arrived in Egypt and is now residing at Hotel du Nil, Cairo. All retailers of post-cards should without fail see the collection, which he has now at his disposal for the Egyptian market. This collection is unique in the world. No time, or expense has been spared in the production of these post cards, which are veritable reproductions of aquarelles.

div.head: Vacuum Oil Company S.A.F.
div.p: NOTICE.

The offices of the V.O.C. have been transferred from Rue Francois Coste No.5 (near Caracol Minet-el-Bassal) to No 6, Bonlevard de R mleh, Daban's Buildings. Any persons desire us to transact business are invited to call at the new primiar.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: Mr. P.P. Graves is the Correspondent of the Egyptian Gazette at Cairo.
All communications for him should be addressed to Pension Wales, Sharia-el- Manakh.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880
Editor & Manager : B. Snelling
Price one P???re Tariff.
FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1904

div.head: THE GUILDHALL SPEECH
div.p: Our telegrams to-day state that the Guildhall Speech has created a generally favourable impression, and in view of the possibilities of a peaceful ending to the dangerous situation of the last few days, Lord Lansdowne was naturally somewhat justified in his optimistic tone. But nothing is more dangerous than the feeling of false security, and the latest London newspapers to hand tend to show that the opinion is steadily gaining ground that the end of the crisis is not yet, but that the present period of comparative calm is but the precursor of a situation fraught with dangerous possibilities.
(ADD COLUMN BREAK)

The constitution of the Tribunal before which, under the Hague Convention, the evidence of both sides will immediately be laid, is regarded as by no means favourable to the British conceptions of the duties of belligerents towards neurtals at sea. Above all, the question is asked, What will be the attitude of the British Government in the event of the Tribunal finding that, under all the circumstances, Admiral Rostjestvensky was justified in the action he took. Such a decision would, it is believed, be received with indignation at home and the hands of the Government would need to be strengthened by the admission of the public of the existence of an exceptionally strong Russian case in order to allay an excitement that might readily bring us again to the verge of war. Even if the Tribunal decide in favour of Great Britain, the ultimate pubishment of the guilty officers will rest solely with the Government of the Tsar. The moment a decision is arrived at the matter passes beyond the jurisdiction of the Tribunal, and it is most improbable that immediate and adequate punishment will be meted out by a Government convinced of the integrity and honour of its officers. Another danger is that the Board of Trade inquiry, upon whosse decision the British public will rely with perfect confidence, may conceivably be. diametrically opposed to the decision of the International Inquiry. Such a situation would be one of exceeding danger where the angry feelings of the nation has been roused by an outrage of particular wantonness.

Lord Lansdowne was on firmer ground when he alluded to the cordial relations with France. Who would have believed, even a couple of years ago, that in the event of a serious difference between England and Russia, France would be playing the part of a moderator, and using all her influence to keep her Ally in the path of peace? That France has done this is unquestionable ; but it is even permissible to ask if she has not done yet more. We have no right to say positively, because we do not know it for certain, that France gave Russia to understand, either directly or indirectly, that her sword would not be drawn against England in a quarrel which was not of England's seeking, and in which France had no concern except to prevent war if she could. But, there are very strong grounds for the belief that France would not have intervened against England , and that the fact was fully recognized at St. Petersburg.

div.head: THE ANGLO-FRENCH CONVENTION
div.p: The Havas Agency publishes a telegraphic resume to-day of the speech of M. Delcasse in the Chamber of Deputies yesterday. The Anglo-French Convention, it will be remembered, consists of three separate decorations : the first dealing with Egypt and Morocco : the second, with Siam, Madagascar, and the New Hebrides : the third, with Newfoundland and West and Central Africa. All points of the Convention have come in for a certain amount of criticism. It is, indeed, clear that there are many Frenchmen who cannot easilt resign themselves to the abandonment of that position of influence on the Nile, which has been a persistent fFrench interest ever since Bonaparte (LINE ILEGIBLE) That is quite human, and natural in men whose race combines the sentimental with the practical in a degree unequalled, perhaps, elsewhere than in France. Again, a compromise by which France abandons her historic rights on the "French Shore" of Newfoundland undoubtedly severs, if with a friendly hand, the last link in a long chain of historical associations. The ghosts of the two hundred years of of international rivalry, of treaties extending from that of Ryswick to that of Versailles, of the great struggle for the dominion of the continent of North America, lurk in the privileges of the French fishermen on the coast of Newfoundland. Nevertheless, business is business, and Frenchmen know that well. Wherefore we do not doubt that the majority of the Chamber and the Senate will adopt M. Delcasse's opinion on the subject.

div.head: PORT ARTHUR.
div.p: JAPANESE REPULSES.
EXPLOSION OF MAGAZINE>
Tokio, November 10.

Owing to the configuration of the groundm the Itz-shan fort has proved a costly obstacle to the Japanese. During fierce assaults which took place on the 5th and 6th inst. the Japanese were repulsed, although during the second assault a casual shell exploded in the Russian mines, killing and wounding between 600 and 700 men.
The Army warehouse at Port Arthur was bombarded with heavy guns. A conflagration ensued, and the magazine at Sun-su-shan exploded.
(Reuter)

div.head: MANCHURIA.
div.p: ALL QUIET.
Tokio, November 10.
With the exception of outpost skirmishes, which took place on the 8th inst., all is quiet in Manchuria.
(Reuter)

div.head: JAPANESE LOAN.
div.p: Tokio, November 10.
The subscriptions for the internal loan menntioned on the 4th inst. have closed. They amounted to 242 million yens.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: VESSELS IN SUDA BAY.
Suda, November 10.
The cruiser Svetliana and four torpedo-boats, together with the Voronejand three colliers, have arrived.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE PROPOSED PEACE CONFERENCE.
div.p: REFERENCE BY LORD LANSDOWNE.
London, November 10.
Lord Lansdowne's speech has produced an excellent impression.

The Morning Post is still dissatisfied, and declares that Lord Lansdowne spoke as if he were an apologist for Russia. The Government has not yet learned the proper use of a strong navy for the preservation of peace with honour
(Reuter)

div.head: MT. ROOSEVELT'S SUCCESS.
div.p: New York, November 10.

The Republican majority in the House will be 100. This remarkable triumph of Mr. Roosevelt is ascribed to popular admiration of this typical American, and also to general approval of his imperialistic policy
(Reuter)

div.head: AMERICAN NAVY.
div.p: CONSTRUCTION OF NEW SHIPS.
Washington, November 10.
Congress will be asked to vote £8,250,000 for the construction of new men-of-war, which includes 3 battleships and 5 fast cruisers.

div.head: THE SYVETON CASE
div.p: Paris, November 10.
M. Syveton, who was arrested as he was about to fight a duel with Captain Degail, was afterwards released.
(Havas.)

div.head: CHURCH AND STATE IN FRANCE.
div.p: Paris, November 10.
CHAMBER OF DEPUTIES- M. Combes has laid the Bill for the separation of the churches from the State before the House.
(Havas.)

div.head: ANGLO-FRENCH CONVENTION
div.p: DEBATE IN FRENCH CHAMBER.
Paris, November 10
CHAMBER OF DEPUTIES.- MM. de Pressense and Jaurés approve the Anglo French treaty.

Replying to the criticisms of M. Cochin concerning Egypt, M. Delcassé said that it was in the interests of France that he took the responsibility of signing the convention. He reminded him that the Caisse de la Dette was created in 1876. Ten years later the interest was reduced and the Debt unified. "We were nearing the time the redemin. tion could be effected; must we refuse our aksent to the redemption of the Debt? I did not think so, but I wished to get something out of our assent. It is laid down that the receipts fromthe Land Tux will bedevoted to the payment of the Domains Debt. Itis undeniable that this financial arrangementis equally favour able to Egypt and to the bondholders. The right of our directing the Antiquities Service is recognised; the guarantee that nothing will happen to compromise our schools is granted to us. I am therefore justified in saying that all our intereste, moral and material, in Egypt are safeguarded."
The debate will be continued on Saturday.
(Havas.)

div.head: THE FRENCH STEAM YACHT
div.p: Fiorentino arrived in Alexandria harbour yesterday.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: The 8th Battalion arrived in Cairo from Alexandria yesterday, going up by special train.

div.head: AN ANGLO-EGYPTIAN SYBDICATE
div.p: Has succeeded in obtaining a concession with a view to the exploitation of the Island of Spetsais as a summer resort.

div.head: A PETITION
div.p: has been presented by the petty employes of the Finance Ministry praying for an increase of their salaries in consequence of the higher cost of living now prevalent.

div.head: ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS.
div.p: The management of the Continental Hotel has engaged the services of MM. Januske and Rigon, whose concerts at the Gambrinus Bar, Milan, met with great success.

div.head: ENGLISH CHILD DROWNED IN THE NILE.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon Willie Gibson, the little son of Conductor Gibson, A.O.D., was playing in the barrack square at Kasr el-Nil. He strayed on to the Nile bank and fell into the river and was drowned. This is the third drowning fatality to soldiers' children at Kasr el-Nil since 1896.

div.head: STATE DOMAIN BONDS.
div.p: Messrs. N.M. Rothschild and Sons announce that a drawing amounting to £20,220 nominal capital of the Egyptian State Domain Mortgage Bonds will take place this month in accordance with the terms of the general bond of this loan. The numbers and descriptions of the bonds drawn will be advertised, and all bonds so drawn will ceaseto bear interest from December 1.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: On the 8th inst., 17 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 10 were British, 2 German, 1 Austrian, 1 Norwegian, 1 Dutch, 1 American, and 1 Italian. The transit and passenger dues for the day amounted to 292,075.80 frs. The total transit and passenger dues collected from the 1st to that date on 97 vessels amounted to 2,517,674.87 frs.

div.head: A.L.M. & D.S.
div.p: The opening concert of the A.L.M. & D.S. for the season 1904-5 will take place (by kind permission of Mr. Abbate) in the Hotel Abbate on Saturday, 3rd December, when a good programme will be provided by the Committee. The choral union of the society is starting its practices on Monday next and hopes to have some part songs ready for the concert. It is under the able conductorship of Mr. Walter Sarjeant, and as the St. Mark's choir is taking part in the chorus we may expect some delightful part singing.

div.head: PASSENGER LISTS.

div.head: GOLD IN EGYPT.
div.p: NILE VALLEY OPERATIONS.
We have received the following information regarding the mining operations of the Nile Valley Company, Ltd.

The company have erected a 250-H.P. Babcock and Wilcox steam boiler and are at the present time also making use of an Evans pump capable of throwing 8,000 gallons per hour in No. 1. shaft. This pump is driven by steam direct.

The machinery now in motion, or being transported to the mines, consists of 5 stamps, the nucleus of a 10 stamp Frazer and Chalmers mill, the stamps weighing. 1,240lbs. It is hoped that the mill will be at work by the Ist of February. A nine-inch Cornish lift is to be used in No. 5 main.shaft.

A level has been driven on a vein at 108 feet and follows the vein for about 1,100 feet. No. 1 shaft is in course of sinking on the vein to 200 feety when No. 2 level will be driven, the depth reached at present being about 155 feet. The intermediate level is driven N..to S. from No. 1 shaft at 150 feet, proving the existence of rich strata. Rich visible gold has been met with in several places along the 108 feet level in which level winges are being sunk at about every 100 feet.

No 5 shaft is being stuffed to 13X5 foet and will be the main shaft. For its present depth it is stuffed and timbered for about 140 feet. It will hereafter be sunk to eut the vein at an estimated depth of 500 feet, Crossents are being put in and driven to interseet the vein every 100 feet from 200 feet downwards. The ore at sight and at grass ready for mill. ing amounts to some 4,500 tons. Retaring to the 108-feet level, a winge has been sunk close to No. 1 shaft to a depth of 30 feet, passing through some very rich stone. Visible gold is still showing in the north face, a couple of shots here a fortnight ago bringing down stone from which some £4,000 was won.
The rich strake appears to be dipping north, and it is hoped that in the course of the next few days it will be picked up in the interme-dinte level.
Prospects are generally very encouraging for future work. Labour is abundant, and on the whole very satisfactory as to quality.

Transport, both hauling and carrying, is entirely worked by means of camels. 'The company hopes during the cold senson to start work by diamond drill to prove the eopper proposition at Absciel and to open up other old workings known to exist on the concession. In addition, prospecting will be vigorously carried on.

div.head: LAND EXPROPRIATIONS.
div.p: A series of Khedivial decrees were published yesterday relating to the expropriation of land to be acquired by the Government for the purpose of irrigation works and buildings at Maghagha, for the construction of embankments, and to serve as sites for Moslem and Coptic cemeteries in various localities.

div.head: JUDICIAL APPOINTMENTS.
div.p: The following appointments have been published: -
Moharrem Ghanem Effendi to be 1st-class judge of the Native Tribunal of Beni-Souef.
Ahmed Abd-el-Razak Effendi to be 2nd-class judge of the Cairo Native Tribunal.
Hussein Darwish Effendi to be 3rd-class judge of the Cairo Native Tribunal.

div.head: THE LATE TIGRANE PASHA.
div.p: The body of the late Tigrane Pasha is expected to arrive in Cairo on Tuesday next. The funeral of the deceased will take place at 10 a.m of that day. The procession will form up at the deceased;s house, whence it will proceed to the Armenian Church in the Mousky.

div.head: RAILWAY ADMINISTRATION.
div.p: The price agreed upon between the Egyptian Railway Administration and Messrs. Milburn and Watts, Watts, of Cardiff, for the supply of 250,000 tons of coal during the coming year is 11s. 3 ½d. f.o.b. In the coal trade it is ocnsidered that the Egyptian Railway Administration have made a good bargain as the price is exceptionally low, considering that Cardiff coal is now in very great demand owing to the disturbed political situation prevailing throughout the world.

div.head: RABIES AMONG DOGS.
div.p: We wwould draw the attention of our readers to an important notice of the Alexandria Municipality which appears in another column. The cases of rabies among dogs in the city are increasing to an alarming extent, and it behoves the public to assist the Municipality in their endeavours to cope with the danger. Only last week, we heard of a dog having bitten fice persons in one house in rue d'Allemagne. One of the victims was Mr. L. Polity, of the Bank of Athens, who has gone to Athens to be treated there.

We understand that as the system of poisoning dogs gives in some cases unfavourable results, it has been decided to charge several members of the police force with the duty of shooting all pariah dogs in the city. This new rule will come into force as from the beginning of next week.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL,
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh

First-Class Hotel-Newly built Sea breezes Dry air. Near tramway station, the promenade, and the Mustapha Pasha Barracks. Gardenm Lawn Tennis. Good cuisine. Moderate charges. Open all the year round. C. AQUILINA, proprietor. (Late of Thos. Cook & Son) ; also General Manager, Tewfik Palace Hotel. Helouan.

div.head: GREEK FLEET'S VISIT.
div.p: GALA PERFORMANCE AT THE ABBAS.
Yesterday evening a grand performance was given at the Abbas Helmy Theatre in honour of the Commodore and officers of the Greek Fleet. The programme was as follows:
﻿﻿﻿1. Second act of the opera Aida;
﻿﻿﻿3. The "Dream," executed by the orchestra of the operatic company and the chorus of the Philharmonic Society;
﻿﻿4. Third act of the opera Aida;
﻿﻿﻿5. Hymn to Greece, music by S. de Marzi, words by C. Garzoni, executed by the orchestra and the chorus of the opera company.
﻿﻿﻿6. The "Guardian of the Nation," executed by the archestra and the opera company, the chorus of the Philharmonic Society, and the tenor, M. Papadopoulo.
﻿﻿﻿7. The Hymn of the: Philharmonic Society, executed by the chorus and the baud of the Philharmonie Society and the orghestra of the орега company.

The theatre has seldom presented such a brilliant and gay appearance as it did yesterday night, being crammed from floor to oiling with am enthusiastic audience. The proceedinga commenced with the Greek. Hymn, on the appearance of the Greek Diplomatic Agent and the Greek Commodore and his Staff.

At the end of the Greek Hymn the whole audience, standing up, burst into loud and enthusiastic cheers and applause for the Nation and the Fleet. Soon after, on the appearance of HE. Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, the Governor of Alexandria, the band played the Egyptian Anthem, which the entire audience received standing, and which terminated also with loud applause, the Governor acknowledging with salutes.

Almost all of the officers of the Fleet and a great number of petty officers and sailors were present. In the right-hand box, looking into the stage, were the members of the committee for the reception of the Fleet: Mr. and Mrs. B. Benachi, Mr. and Mrs. M. Sinadino, Mr. S. Salvago, the Greek Diplomatic Agent, Mr. Gennadis, and M. Sinopoulo, of the Greek Consulate of Alexandria. In the opposite box, to the left, were Commodore D. Coundouriotis and his staff, Captain Ghinis, of the flagship Psara, the Greek Consul-General, Mr. Scotidis, and Mr. and Mrs. A. Benachi The boxes exactly facing the stage were reserved exclusively for the officers of the Fleet, and the other boxes were filled by all the leading members of the Greek community and their families, and also by the Greek naval officers. The whole row of the third tier was alinost exclusively occupied by the sailorsof the Fleet. All the notables of the Greek colony and their families were present, and the brilliant toilettes of the ladies, together with the uniforms of the officers and sailors, made a very fine effect.

The spirits, too, ofthe audience were excel-lent, and it manifested its enthusiasm repeat-edly by loud and prolonged applause. Nearly every piece in the programme was repeated, so loud and long was the applause, and at the end of the Hymn to the Fleet, the stirring and patriotie words of which had raised the enthusiasm of the sudience to fever heat, the applause was perfectly thundering and over-whelming. Mr. Nicolas Sinadino, the composer of the piece, was repeatedly and enthusiastic. ally called for, and from a box on the left he acknowledged the cheers by repested bows In general, all the pieces executed were of a patriotie character, in connection with the Greek nation, army and fleet, and it must be remarked that the observer could not but be touched and impressed by the intense and sincere spirit of patriotism which prevailed among the entire audience and offioers and men of the fleet, and which was exprossed so repeatedly and spontaneously after every piece represented.

The proceedings closed with the playing of the Greek National Anthem, executed by the chorus and band of the Philharmonie Society, together together with the orchestra of the opers company, and after loudly cheering the Commodore and officers the audience dispersed.

Among those present we noted, besides the Commodore D. Coundouriotis and his staff, the Greek Diplomatie Agent, Mr. Genna-dis and all the members of the GreekConsulate; Mr. and Mrs. E. Benachi, Mr. and Mrs. M. Sinalino, Mr. and Mrs. S. Benachi, Mr. and Mrs. Salvago, Mr. and Mrs. Choremi, Mr. Civitanidis, Mr. G. Cartalis, Mr. S. Sinalino, Mr. N. Sinadino, Mr. and. Mrs. Aslan, Mr. J. Pestazoglou, Mr. and Mrs. Joannidis, Mr. C. and Mrs. C. Strenunai, Mr. and Mrs. G. Strenunai and Mr. D. Strenunzi, Mr. and Mrs, D. Tavoudis, Mr. and Mrs. D. Papageorge, and many others.

Commodore Coundouriotis and the officers of the Greek Squadron were "at home" on the Eagship Para yesterday afternoon. There was a large gathering of Greek and other notabi-lities, and dancing - was engaged in to the strains of the ship's band.

H.E. the Governor of Alexandria is giving a dinner to Commodore Coundouriotisand the oficers. to-morrow evening- at his house in Moharrem Bey. Afterwards his Excelleney and his guests will attend a 'special performance of I Trovatore at the Abbas Helmy Theatre.

div.head: EDEN PALACE HOTEL,
div.p: CAIRO.
Open all the year round.
ELECTRIC LIGHT.-LIFT.-MODERATE CHARGES

div.head: KING'S BIRTHDAY.
div.p: Major-General Slade, C.B., Commanding the Army of Ocoupation, telegraphed on Wednesday to his Mejesty the -King as followns.
"General Slade, and Oficers of the Arny of Occupation, offer their loyal com gratalations to His Majesty.25.
The following gracious reply has been received
The King thanks you and tbe Officers of the -Army of Occupations for your messago of loyal, congratulation: on His Majesty's. Birthday 2
Maj.-Gen: Slade. gave. a dinner. on the night of the birthday of H.M. the King to which many of the principal offiosts.of the British Garrison were invited.

The reception held at H.B.M,'s Consulate, Alexandria, on the occasion of the King's Birthday, was very largely nttended, a representative gathering being present to congratulate his Majesty's representative on the auspicious occasion. Mr. and Mra. Gould received the numerous visitors with their wonted affability. Besides the members of the British colony, there were many representatives of the foreign colonies, including several con-suls, and the Commodore, and officers of the Greek Squadron at present in the harbour.

div.head: BALTIC FLEET
div.p: The cruisers Admiral Nakhimofand Dimitri Donskoi will probably pass through the Suez Canal in company with the other vessels of Admiral Folkersam's division. The Dimitri Donskoi is becoming quite an old friend. This will be her third visit to Egyptian waters in the course of the year.

A posse of 45 police has been sent to Port Said in view of the approaching passage of the Russian ships. This, however, is no unusual thing when large squadrons are expected to pass through the Canal.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE.
div.p: During the week ending yesterday, there were 25 deaths from bovine typhus in the whole of Egypt, as against 33 in the previous week. Two new localities have been reported infected, El Kharaba and Abouzahera.

During the week a large number of inoculations were made, with good results, in the neighbourhood, of all villages where bovine typhus was reported. The total number of inoculations for the week was 2,817.

div.head: RAMLEH ELECTRIC RAILWAY.
div.p: The new deep-level reserve cable for the Rainieh Bloetrio Railway has - been asod daily. for the-last fortnight and has given great satisfaction, the service being very regular. The old one is used now as a reserve cable.

Next week, the company will commence laying the rails on the new prolongation of the Ramleh-boulevard line running along the new quay. The line will run parallel to the present one, which it will replace, as the land by the terminus has been sold.

The plans for the extension of the Railway to Mohamed Aly-square along the quay have not yet been sanctioned by the Municipality. The terminus of the line will temporarily be by the side of the present station, and, will be close to the quay. The present terminus will Le handed over to the purebasens of the land nest February.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE.
div.p: This evening a second gala of performance will take place on the occasion of the birthday of H.M. King Victor Emmanuel. The piece chosen for representation is Faust.
It is interesting to note that Miss Zoe Nesleda, the charming prima donna, who takes the part of Marguerite in Faust, is the niece of the late Ambassador ant Stambiul, Sir William White.

div.head: RABIES AMONG DOGS.
div.p: IMPORTANT NOTICE.

The Municipality consider it very necessary to draw the attention of the public to the fact that Rabies among Dogs is at the present moment greatly on the increase. No less than four persons have died from rabies in the year 1904, and of these two in the last month.
As the Vete inary Service was not advised by these persons when they were bitten, the dogs were allowed to remain at large.
Again, no less than 17 persons have been bitten to the knowledge of the Municipality in the last 2 months.

It is most essential that anyone bitten by a dog, cat, horse, or any other animal should at once advise the Veterinary Service of the Municipality (Telephone 1150) so that the animal can be caught and the necessary precautions taken.

It should be well understood that this should be done even though the animal may appear to be in perfect health-for it is only by examination that it can be ascertained if the animal is suffering from rabies.
The Municipality are determined to do their utmost to remove this scourge- but they are almost powerless unless assisted by the public.
(Signed) : W.P. CHATAWAY,
Administrator.
Alexandria, November 10. 24,886-8-1

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: TheS.S. Kaffir Prince, from London, left Malta on Thursday and is due here on Monday next, with passengers and general cargo.
The S.S. Asiatic Prince left London on Wednesday, with passengers and general cargo, for Malta and Alexandria.
The Khedivial Mail S.S. Ismailia will leave Alexandria on Wednesday for Pirseus, Smyrna, M??lene, and Constantinople.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Khedive attended prayers to-day at Koubbeh Mosque.
Marquis Salvago-Raggi. Italian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General, is, expected.in Cairo on the 20th inst.
Sir E. Cassel left London yesterday week for Liverpool on his way to New York.
Chitty Bey, Director of customs, has left for Cairo on business connected with the administration
Dr. Rucker-Jenisch is expeoted to arrive in Egypt on Monday next,
The Governor of Alexandria paid-a visit: this morning to the Italian Cousel, on then occasion of the Italian King's Birthday. His Excellency will visit the Royal Italian. school, at 3 tAm.

Lieut-Col. Mantell, R.B., has returned from leave of absence. while Mr. and Mrs. Bell and Miss Bell have returned to 18, Grosvenot Orescent from North-umberland, and leave for lgypt at the end of this month
The latest arrivals at the Grand Continentel Hotel include. Mr. Dunbar Kilbur,-CaptA. A Cameron Bey, and- CaptiSweony, Boyaliuve siliers.

Amongst the latest arrivals at the Bistern, Exchange Hotel, Port Said, are Mr. A.P, James, Mr. T.H. A. Evans, Mr. and Mrs. W. J. Adams, Mr. J. Stuart, Mr. Henry Rittener, Mr. and Mrs. B Tillard, Mr. H. H. Thompson, | Mr. M. do Levalette, Lieut. R.H. Young, Mr. G. Bostock, Mr. W. Soott-Hill, Mr. C. Crossland.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: FOOTBALL.
RAS-El-TIN vs. MUSTAPHA.

One of the hardest and fastest games ever seen at Ras-el-Tin was fought out by the teams mentioned above yesterday. From start to finish the game was full of life and excitement. In the first half the soldiers pressed and scored from a penalty. The school almost monopolised the play in the second half and scored a magnificent goal through Mr. Hickling. Two more goals were disallowed for various reasons. "Jumping" by one of the school "halves" was the one blot on the game.

Teams:- Mustapha.- Goal, Pte. Ware;backs, Cpl. Fitzgerald and Cpl. Wellington ; ½ backs, Cp;. Quintan, Cpl. Murphy, Cpl. Hutchings ; forwards Cp;. Isaacs, Pte. H. Cowie, Cpl. Shea, Savage, Pte. Thomson.
Ras-el-Tin.-Goal, Bekir ; backs, Amin and Hassan ; ½ backs, Fahmy, Moharrem, Gamal, forwards, Selim, Mr. Hickling, Gharbi, Mr. McPherson, Geleel.

div.head: ST. ANDREW'S F>C.
div.p: The above club gas arrabged a match with teh Departmental Corps, Royal Berks, to take place on the parade ground at Mustapha Pasha barracks to-morrow afternoon at 8.30. The following will represent St. Andrew's:- Fitzgerald, Bright, Keill, George, Wilson, Hutchins, Sweet, Jones, Cowie, Tulloch, and Halley. Reserve : Williams. The team will meet at Ramleh station at 3 p.m.

div.head: BAND PERFORMACE.
div.p: In honour of the Birthday of H.M. the King of Italy, and by kind permission of Major C.J.L. Davidson, D.S.O., Commanding, and officers 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the band will play the following programme on the terrace of the Grand Continental Hotel to-night from 8 to 11 o/clock
March- Le Regiment Favori-D. Eril.
Bplero- Leggerio Invisible-Arditi.
Overture-Tanderedi-Rossini.
Valse- Donan Weller-Ivanovicei.
Selection- Cavalleria Rusticans-Masdagui.
Song- I'll Sing abe songs of Araby-Clay.
Piccolo solo-Deep Blue Sea-Solomon.
Selection- Folk Song of Italy-Raulpeazetti.
Valse Bleue- Maryio.
Intermezzo-Marie-Williams.
Khedivial Anthem.
God Save the King.
